name: Binary

unions.name: Bits
unions.comment:
**The binary sequence.**

Use converters to make `Bits`.

    Binary.fromIntegers [ 0, 1, 0, 1 ]

values.name: add
values.comment:
Add two sets of bits together.

    -- ADD 1011
    --     1011
    --  = 10110

    >>> add
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 1, 1 ])
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 1, 1 ])
    fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 1, 1, 0  ]

    >>> add
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 1, 1, 1, 0, 1 ])
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 1, 0 ])
    fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1  ]

values.name: and
values.comment:
AND operator.

    --     0101 (decimal 5)
    -- AND 0011 (decimal 3)
    --   = 0001 (decimal 1)

    >>> Binary.and
    ..>   (fromHex "5")
    ..>   (fromHex "3")
    ensureSize 4 (fromHex "1")

values.name: append
values.comment:
Merge two binary sequences.

    >>> append
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ])
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 1, 0 ])
    fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 1, 0 ]

values.name: chunksOf
values.comment:
Split the binary sequence in multiple chunks.

    >>> fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 1, 0 ]
    ..>   |> chunksOf 4
    ..>   |> List.map toIntegers
    [ [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ]
    , [ 1, 0, 1, 0 ]
    ]

values.name: concat
values.comment:
Concat multiple binary sequences.

    >>> [ fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ]
    ..> , fromIntegers [ 0, 1, 0, 1 ]
    ..> ]
    ..>   |> concat
    ..>   |> toDecimal
    133

values.name: dropLeadingZeros
values.comment:
Drops the leading zeros of a binary sequence.

    >>> dropLeadingZeros (fromIntegers [ 0, 0, 1, 0 ])
    fromIntegers [ 1, 0 ]

values.name: empty
values.comment: An empty binary sequence.

values.name: ensureSize
values.comment:
Ensure the binary sequence length is of certain size.

    >>> ensureSize 4 (fromIntegers [ 1, 0 ])
    fromIntegers [ 0, 0, 1, 0 ]

values.name: fromBooleans
values.comment:
Convert a list of booleans to `Bits`.

    >>> fromBooleans [ True, False, False, False ] |> toHex
    "8"

values.name: fromDecimal
values.comment:
Convert a decimal to `Bits`.

    >>> fromDecimal 8 |> toIntegers
    [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ]

values.name: fromHex
values.comment:
Convert a hex string to list of binary numbers.

    >>> fromHex "8" |> toIntegers
    [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ]

values.name: fromIntegers
values.comment:
Convert a list of integers to `Bits`.

Everything below zero and zero itself becomes a `0` bit,
and everything above zero becomes a `1` bit.

    >>> fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ] |> toHex
    "8"

values.name: fromString
values.comment:
Convert a string to `Bits`.

The resulting bits will represent the decimal value
(ie. code point) of each character (it uses `String.toList`).

The first argument determines how many bits
are used per decimal value.

WARNING: This assumes each character will fit into the range you defined.
For example, an emoji will not fit in 8 bits, so you can't use `fromString 8`.
That said, you can use `fromStringAsUtf8` to make sure each character
is split up into multiple UTF-8 characters.

    -- 1 character
    -- Code points: [ 0x1F936 ]

    >>> "ðŸ¤¶"
    ..>   |> fromString 32
    ..>   |> toHex
    "0001F936"

    -- 3 characters
    -- Code points: [ 0x61, 0x62, 0x63 ]
    -- These hexadecimal values are each 8 bits long.

    >>> "abc"
    ..>   |> fromString 8
    ..>   |> toHex
    "616263"

values.name: fromStringAsUtf8
values.comment:
Convert a string to UTF-8 `Bits`.

This will convert every character into multiple UTF-8 codepoints,
if necessary, and then use 8 bits per character.

NOTE: This is not the same as the `fromString 8` function!
Which assumes every character is already UTF-8.
Or, in other words, assumes that each character's codepoint is below 128.

    >>> "ðŸ¤¶"
    ..>   |> fromStringAsUtf8
    ..>   |> toHex
    "F09FA4B6"

    >>> "abc"
    ..>   |> fromStringAsUtf8
    ..>   |> toHex
    "616263"

values.name: makeIsometric
values.comment:
Makes two sequences isometric (equal in size).

    >>> makeIsometric
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 0, 1, 0 ])
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ])
    ( fromIntegers [ 0, 0, 1, 0 ]
    , fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ]
    )

values.name: not
values.comment:
NOT operator.

    -- NOT 0111 (decimal 7)
    --   = 1000 (decimal 8)

    >>> Binary.not
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 0, 1, 1, 1 ])
    fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ]

values.name: or
values.comment:
OR operator.

    --    0101 (decimal 5)
    -- OR 0011 (decimal 3)
    --  = 0111 (decimal 7)

    >>> Binary.or
    ..>   (fromHex "5")
    ..>   (fromHex "3")
    fromHex "7"

values.name: rotateLeftBy
values.comment:
Rotate a binary sequence to the left.

_NOTE: Make sure your binary sequence is of the correct size before rotating!
Rotating 8 bits is not always the same as, for example, 16 bits._

    >>> rotateLeftBy 1 (ensureSize 32 <| fromHex "17")
    ensureSize 32 (fromHex "2E")

    >>> rotateLeftBy 2 (ensureSize 32 <| fromHex "96")
    ensureSize 32 (fromHex "258")

values.name: rotateRightBy
values.comment:
Rotate a binary sequence to the right.

_NOTE: Make sure your binary sequence is of the correct size before rotating!
Rotating 8 bits is not always the same as, for example, 16 bits._

    >>> rotateRightBy 1 (ensureSize 64 <| fromHex "17")
    ensureSize 64 (fromHex "800000000000000B")

    >>> rotateRightBy 1 (ensureSize 32 <| fromHex "96")
    ensureSize 32 (fromHex "4B")

    >>> rotateRightBy 5 (ensureSize 32 <| fromHex "96")
    ensureSize 32 (fromHex "B0000004")

values.name: shiftLeftBy
values.comment:
Arithmetic/Logical left shift.

    -- LEFTSHIFT 00010111 (decimal 23)
    --         = 00101110 (decimal 46)

    >>> [ 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 1, 1, 1 ]
    ..>   |> fromIntegers
    ..>   |> shiftLeftBy 1
    ..>   |> toIntegers
    [ 0, 0, 1, 0, 1, 1, 1, 0 ]

values.name: shiftRightBy
values.comment:
Arithmetic right shift.

    -- ARI-RIGHTSHIFT 10010111 (decimal 151)
    --              = 11001011 (decimal 203)

    >>> [ 1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 1, 1, 1 ]
    ..>   |> fromIntegers
    ..>   |> shiftRightBy 1
    ..>   |> toIntegers
    [ 1, 1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 1, 1 ]

values.name: shiftRightZfBy
values.comment:
Logical right shift.

    -- LOG-RIGHTSHIFT 10010111 (decimal 151)
    --              = 00001011 (decimal 11)

    >>> [ 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 1, 1, 1 ]
    ..>   |> fromIntegers
    ..>   |> shiftRightZfBy 1
    ..>   |> toIntegers
    [ 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 1, 1 ]

values.name: subtract
values.comment:
Subtract two sets of bits from each other.

    -- SUBTRACT 1011
    --          11
    --        = 1010

    >>> subtract
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 1, 1 ])
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 1, 1 ])
    fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0  ]

    >>> subtract
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0, 1 ])
    ..>   (fromIntegers [ 0, 0, 1, 0, 0 ])
    fromIntegers [ 0, 1, 1, 0, 1  ]

values.name: toBooleans
values.comment:
Convert `Bits` to a list of booleans.

    >>> toBooleans <| fromHex "8"
    [ True, False, False, False ]

values.name: toDecimal
values.comment:
Convert `Bits` to a decimal.

    >>> toDecimal <| fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ]
    8

values.name: toHex
values.comment:
Convert a list of binary numbers to a hex string.

    >>> toHex <| fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ]
    "8"

values.name: toIntegers
values.comment:
Convert `Bits` to a list of integers.

    >>> toIntegers <| fromHex "8"
    [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ]

values.name: toString
values.comment:
Convert `Bits` to a string.

1.  Splits the bits in chunks of the given number
2.  Each chunk is converted to a decimal (code point)
3.  Each code point is translated to a character
4.  The list of characters is converted to a string

The first argument determines how many bits
are used per decimal value (ie. how large the chunks are).

    >>> "0001F936"
    ..>   |> fromHex
    ..>   |> toString 32
    "ðŸ¤¶"

    >>> "616263"
    ..>   |> fromHex
    ..>   |> toString 8
    "abc"

values.name: width
values.comment:
Get the amount of bits in a binary sequence.

    >>> fromIntegers [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ]
    ..>   |> width
    4

values.name: xor
values.comment:
XOR operator.

    --     0101 (decimal 5)
    -- XOR 0011 (decimal 3)
    --   = 0110 (decimal 6)

    >>> Binary.xor
    ..>   (fromHex "5")
    ..>   (fromHex "3")
    fromHex "6"
